novel_text:
The ceiling was an unhelpful shade of white. A flat, expansive nothing that stretched from one corniced edge to the other, offering precisely zero solutions to the problem of being Eleanor Vance. It had been her primary confidante for the past six weeks, this ceiling. It had listened to her silent screams, absorbed the frantic thumping of her heart, and watched, dispassionately, as her world shrank from the circumference of the globe to the four walls of a two-bedroom flat overlooking the perpetual traffic of St Peter's Street.

The last time she’d been in the air, the world had tried to shake her out of it. Like a dog with a rat. The flight from Cusco to Lima. It was supposed to be routine, a little puddle-jumper between filming segments for her show, *Vance’s Ventures*. She was the jaunty, unflappable presenter who could charm a snake in Marrakech or navigate the floating markets of the Mekong Delta with a single, winning smile. Unflappable Eleanor Vance. The woman who could eat a witchetty grub without flinching. That woman was dead. She’d died somewhere over the Andes, at thirty-seven thousand feet, during a bout of turbulence so violent it had thrown a flight attendant into the overhead lockers.

It wasn't the shaking, not really. It was the sound. A deep, guttural groan from the belly of the aircraft, a sound of metal being asked to do something it was never designed to do. And then the drop. Not a dip, not a lurch, but a sickening, stomach-hollowing plunge into thin air, a freefall that lasted only a few seconds but had permanently rewired her brain. In those seconds, she had known, with a certainty that eclipsed all other knowledge, that she was going to die. The universe had contracted to the dimensions of her seat, to the frantic grip of her own hands on the armrests, the plastic sweating against her palms. She hadn't screamed. She had simply stopped breathing, her body a rigid vessel of pure, distilled terror. When the plane finally stabilised, when the captain’s absurdly calm voice crackled over the intercom apologising for the “spot of weather,” a woman a few rows ahead had begun to weep. A low, animal sound of pure relief. Eleanor had just sat there, staring at the back of the seat in front of her, a stranger in her own body.

Now, the loudest sound was the hum of the fridge and the distant, mournful cry of a siren. St Albans. Home. It had always been her anchor, the quiet, historic city she returned to after her whirlwind trips. The Roman walls of Verulamium, the ancient stones of the Abbey, the Saturday market teeming with life. It was meant to be a sanctuary. It had become a cage. Her passport sat in a drawer, gathering dust like a relic from a forgotten civilization. Her suitcase, usually in a state of semi-permanent packing, was shoved in the back of a wardrobe, zipped shut on a life she no longer knew how to lead.

Her phone buzzed on the coffee table, a frantic, angry vibration against the wood. The screen lit up with a name that made her stomach clench. *Marcus.* Of course. She watched it vibrate, a small black harbinger of doom. He’d been patient for the first two weeks, sympathetic for the third, and was now entering a phase of barely-concealed exasperation. She let it go to voicemail, the silence that followed the buzzing somehow more accusatory than the noise itself. A minute later, it buzzed again. A text.

*Ellie, pick up. We HAVE to talk. The network is asking about the Seychelles shoot.*

The Seychelles. Just the word made her feel dizzy. An archipelago of islands floating in an endless expanse of blue. Blue water. Blue sky. And the only way to get there was in a pressurised metal tube, a coffin with wings. She squeezed her eyes shut, the memory of the drop rising in her throat like bile. The phone rang again, insistent. This time, she knew he wouldn't give up. With a sigh that seemed to pull up stones from the bottom of her soul, she answered.

"Marcus."

"Ellie-cat! Thank God. I was about to send a search party. Are you alright? You sound like you're at the bottom of a well." His voice was a slick, professional performance of concern.

"I'm fine, Marcus. Just… tired."

"Tired? Darling, you've had six weeks off. Most people would be climbing the walls with boredom. I'm sure St Albans is lovely, all that history, but it’s not exactly the Amazon, is it?" He chuckled, a dry, rustling sound. "Listen, about the Seychelles. Production has the filming permits sorted, the crew is on standby. We're looking at a departure in two weeks. A nice, gentle flight. Direct. Emirates. They have those lovely little washbags, even in premium economy."

Eleanor stared at her ceiling. The unhelpful, stupidly white ceiling. "I can't." The words were small, brittle things.

A pause on the other end of the line. The bonhomie in his voice evaporated, replaced by a cold, hard edge. "What do you mean, you can't? Eleanor, this is the flagship series. *Vance's Ventures: Islands in the Sun*. It's your name on the tin. They've already run the promos."

"I mean I can't get on the plane, Marcus." She heard the tremor in her own voice and hated it. "I told you. After the Peru flight…"

"Oh, for heaven's sake," he snapped, all pretence gone. "It was a bit of turbulence! It happens. You fly a hundred times a year, Ellie. You can’t let one bumpy ride derail your entire career. It's unprofessional."

Unprofessional. The word landed like a slap. She, who had waded through leech-infested waters, who had slept in hammocks in jungles alive with things that bite, who had smiled for the camera while nursing a bout of dysentery that would have felled a lesser mortal. Unprofessional.

"It wasn't a bumpy ride," she said, her voice dangerously quiet. "You weren't there."

"Well, I'm here now, trying to salvage your career!" he shot back. "Do you have any idea how much money is riding on this? The sponsors, the network… they're not going to wait forever. There are a hundred other presenters who would kill for this gig. That girl who does the weekend weather, Chloe something, she's been calling me. Non-stop."

A hot spike of anger, sharp and clean, cut through the fog of fear. Chloe-something. A perky blonde with a surgically-enhanced smile and the intellectual depth of a puddle. "Then give it to Chloe," she said, the words tasting like poison.

"Don't be ridiculous," Marcus hissed. "You're the brand. 'Unflappable Ellie Vance'. We just need to get you back on the horse. Have you tried anything? Hypnotherapy? Gin? A nice, strong sedative?"

"I'm not getting on the plane, Marcus."

Another silence, this one long and cold and full of the sound of contracts being mentally torn up. "Right," he said finally. His voice was flat. "I see. Well. When you've decided to stop this… melodrama… give me a call. But don't leave it too long, Ellie. The world moves on. Even if you don't."

The line went dead. Eleanor held the phone to her ear for a moment longer, listening to the dial tone. Melodrama. He thought this was a choice. A fit of pique. He had no concept of the sheer, primal terror that now lived in her, a cold, heavy parasite curled around her spine. She threw the phone onto the sofa, the bounce unsatisfyingly soft. The flat was silent again, but the silence was different now. It was filled with Marcus’s words, with the phantom calls of Chloe-something, with the tick-tock of her career bleeding out on the beige carpet.

She stood up and walked, aimlessly at first, her bare feet cold on the floorboards. She drifted from the living room into her small study, a room that was once her pride and joy. It was lined with bookshelves groaning under the weight of travel guides, maps, and histories of far-flung places. On one shelf, nestled between a chunk of volcanic rock from Iceland and a hand-carved mask from Papua New Guinea, stood Zara.

Zara was four inches tall, moulded from hard, unyielding plastic, with articulated joints at her shoulders, elbows, and knees. She wore khaki shorts, sturdy-looking boots, and a ridiculously determined expression on her tiny, painted face. Her official name, according to the packaging Eleanor had thrown out years ago, was 'Zara Stryker, Jungle Adventurer'. She came with a plastic machete and a pair of binoculars that didn’t work. Eleanor’s step-father had given her the action figure as a joke gift for her tenth birthday, a "sidekick" for the tomboy who was always climbing trees and scraping her knees. Zara had been her silent co-pilot ever since, a tiny mascot who had lived in her backpack through two dozen countries. Now, she was the only one left who seemed to understand.

Eleanor picked her up. The plastic was cool and solid in her hand. She positioned Zara on the edge of the desk, her little plastic boots dangling over the precipice.

"Well," Eleanor said to the empty room, her voice hoarse. "He thinks it's melodrama."

She waited, a habit she'd never quite broken. In her head, a voice that was hers but not hers, a voice that was braver and more certain, supplied the response. Zara's voice. *Marcus is a suit, El. He thinks a stiff upper lip is a substitute for a spine. What does a desk jockey know about the sky trying to eat you?*

A small, wry smile touched Eleanor’s lips. "He wants to give my show to Chloe-something from the weather."

*Let him,* Zara’s voice shot back, full of bravado. *Her idea of an adventure is finding a parking space at Brent Cross. Good riddance. We don't need their tin can aeroplane anyway. The greatest discoveries aren't made at thirty-seven thousand feet. They're made on the ground. With your boots on.*

Eleanor turned the tiny figure over in her fingers. Zara's painted-on eyes stared back, fierce and uncomplicated. She was right, of course. Or the part of Eleanor's brain that she'd outsourced to a plastic doll was right. The anger from Marcus's call was still there, a hot coal in her chest, and Zara's imagined defiance was fanning it into a small, flickering flame. Melodrama. Unprofessional. Fine. She walked back into the living room, scooped up her phone, and with a decisive tap of her thumb, deleted Marcus’s entire call history and message thread. It was a small, petty act, but it felt like taking a breath after being held underwater. She couldn’t fly. That was a fact, hard and immovable as the Abbey down the street. But maybe, just maybe, she didn’t have to stay grounded.*Boots on the ground.* The thought was so clear, it was almost a sound. It echoed in the new, Marcus-less silence of the flat. For weeks, she had been floating, untethered from her own life, adrift in an ocean of anxiety with only the white ceiling for a sky. Now, an anchor had dropped. It wasn't a solution, not a cure, but it was a point of contact with something solid. She looked down at her bare feet, pale against the dark wood of the floor. She had walked on scorching desert sands and treacherous mountain paths in her career, yet for the past six weeks, the journey from the sofa to the kettle had felt like an expedition. The idea was absurd, terrifying, and utterly necessary. She had to go out.

The decision was a spark, but the execution was wading through mud. A dozen excuses presented themselves immediately. It was late afternoon, it might rain, she hadn't showered, what would she even do out there? The litany of inertia was a familiar, cloying song. She walked to the window and looked down at the street. Cars crawled past, people with shopping bags and determined expressions moved along the pavement, each on their own trajectory, each grounded in the simple, unthinking business of living. They weren't falling from the sky. They were just walking down the street. It looked like the most profound and enviable magic trick she had ever seen. She felt a pang of jealousy so sharp it almost stole her breath. That was the feeling that finally propelled her into motion. Jealousy was better than terror. It was an active, hungry emotion.

In her bedroom, she ignored the wardrobe with its ghost-filled suitcase and instead pulled open a drawer of clothes she hadn't touched since her return. Not the quick-dry, multi-pocketed trousers of her television persona, but a simple pair of jeans. She pulled on a jumper, the soft wool a comforting weight on her shoulders. The final, most important step was footwear. Tucked away under a pile of discarded magazines were her old walking boots. Not the high-tech, brightly-coloured ones the show’s sponsors provided, but a scuffed, well-worn leather pair that had moulded to her feet over a decade of weekend hikes in the Peak District and the Scottish Highlands, long before *Vance’s Ventures* was even a concept. Sliding her feet into them felt like a homecoming. Before she left the study, she paused, then decisively plucked Zara from the desk and slipped the tiny adventurer into her jacket pocket. The hard plastic was a reassuring lump against her hip.

The front door was the final boss. Her hand hovered over the latch, the familiar shape of it suddenly alien. Outside was the world. The big, loud, unpredictable world that contained noise and strangers and open skies. The same sky she had plummeted through. Her heart began to do its familiar frantic drum solo against her ribs. *It's just a street, El,* Zara’s voice piped up in her head, impatient and practical. *Not the summit of K2. You’re not going to get vertigo from the kerb. Get a grip.* Eleanor took a breath, turned the lock, and pulled the door open. The air that hit her was cool and damp, carrying the scent of traffic fumes and rain-soaked stone. The muted hum of the city she’d heard through double-glazing was now a complex symphony of distinct sounds: the squeal of a bus's brakes, the distant chime of the Abbey clock, the murmur of conversation from people passing by. It was overwhelming, a sensory flood after the sterile quiet of the flat.

She took a step out onto the landing, then another down the communal stairs, each footfall on the worn carpet a conscious, deliberate act. When she finally pushed open the heavy main door and stepped onto the pavement of St Peter's Street, she had to stop for a moment, blinking in the grey afternoon light. The sky above was a blanket of soft, uniform cloud, an altogether more helpful shade of grey than the white of her ceiling. There were no gaping expanses of blue, no dizzying heights, just a low, comforting lid on the world. She turned away from the main road, towards the quieter lanes that led to the park. Her walk was hesitant at first, her gaze fixed on the pavement in front of her as if she were navigating a crevasse. But as she moved, a forgotten rhythm began to return to her limbs. She started to look up, to notice things. The intricate brickwork on a Georgian townhouse, a flash of startling green from a parakeet in a tree, the weathered face of a stone gargoyle peering down from a church roof. This was what she did. This was who she was. She was an observer, a collector of details. She had just forgotten how to do it without a camera crew in tow. The journey was only ten minutes, but it felt like crossing a continent. When the ancient Roman wall that bordered Verulamium Park rose up at the end of the lane, solid and implacable, Eleanor stopped. It had stood here for almost two thousand years. It had seen empires rise and fall. It hadn’t fallen out of the sky. She reached out and pressed her palm against the cold, flint-studded surface. It was real. It was solid. And for the first time in six weeks, so was she.The flint was rough under her palm, a mosaic of jagged edges cemented by time. Each stone was an individual, a story, but together they formed a defence that had stood against weather and war. Eleanor traced the line of mortar with her finger, feeling the grit and the cold. She had built her own walls these past weeks, but they were smooth and white and offered no purchase. They were meant to keep the world out, but had only succeeded in trapping her in. This wall was different. It was part of the world, defining a space without imprisoning it.

Following its curve, she walked deeper into the park. The grass was a deep, damp green, softened by the day’s drizzle. A flock of Canada geese paraded near the edge of the lake, honking with self-important indignation as a toddler ran a little too close. The sound was raucous and alive, a world away from the metallic groans of an aeroplane in distress. For her show, she would have framed this shot with the Abbey spire in the background, perhaps getting a low angle to make the geese seem more formidable, narrating a witty voiceover about territorial disputes in the Home Counties. The instinct was still there, a ghost limb of her former profession, but today there was no crew, no shot list, no pressure to perform. There was just the watching.

She found an empty bench facing the water, its wooden slats slick with rain. She sat, placing her hands on her knees, feeling the rough texture of her jeans. She watched a pair of coots paddle in frantic, neurotic circles. She watched a man in a high-vis jacket methodically spearing litter into a black bag. She watched a young couple huddle together under a single, enormous umbrella, their quiet laughter carrying across the water. It was all so profoundly, beautifully ordinary. These people were not thinking about the physics of lift or the tensile strength of a fuselage. Their worlds were not shrinking; they were expanding with every shared joke, every step taken, every mundane task completed. The jealousy she’d felt earlier returned, but it was less sharp now, diluted with a strange sense of wonder.

A wet nose nudged insistently against her hand. Eleanor startled, looking down into the intelligent, whiskery face of a border terrier. The dog’s tail gave a hopeful thump-thump-thump against the leg of the bench.

“Oi, Pip! Leave the lady alone. You’re harassing the public.” The voice was a gravelly, good-natured rumble. An elderly man in a tweed flat cap and a well-worn Barbour jacket shuffled towards them, a leash coiled in his hand. He had a kind, crinkled face and eyes the same pale grey as the sky. “Sorry about him. He has no sense of personal space. Thinks everyone he meets is a long-lost friend with a pocket full of biscuits.”

“It’s alright,” Eleanor said, surprised at how steady her voice sounded. She gave the terrier, Pip, a scratch behind the ears. His fur was wiry and coarse. “He’s very charming.”

“He’s a menace,” the man said with obvious affection, sitting down at the other end of the bench with a slight groan. “Just taking the old boy for his constitutional. We do this every day, rain or shine. Don’t we, Pip?” The dog, having received his quota of affection, settled at the man’s feet with a contented sigh. They sat in a comfortable silence for a moment, two strangers and a dog watching the coots. “It’s a good day for it,” the man said eventually. “Quiet. The park feels like it can breathe a bit, after the weekend.”

“Yes,” Eleanor agreed. “It’s peaceful.”

“You new to St Albans?” he asked, his curiosity gentle. “Don’t think I’ve seen you on our patrol route before.”

The question hung in the air. Was she new? She had owned her flat for five years, but it had only ever been a base camp. She knew the fastest route to Heathrow better than she knew the winding medieval lanes behind the cathedral. “No,” she said slowly. “I’ve lived here a while. Just… haven’t been out much lately.”

The man just nodded, accepting the statement without question or judgment. He pointed with his chin towards the half-excavated remains of a Roman townhouse visible across the grass. “Funny, isn’t it? People come from all over the world to see a few old walls and a bit of floor. But the people who live here, we walk past it every day and barely give it a glance. It’s just the park.” He chuckled to himself. “Took my grandson the other week. He was more interested in the ice cream van. But I told him, I said, ‘Imagine being a Roman, waking up right here. What would you see? No Abbey, no traffic. Just fields and trees and the road to Londinium.’ You don’t have to go to the other side of the world to find a different country. Sometimes it’s just under your feet.”

The words struck Eleanor with the force of a physical blow. *You don’t have to go to the other side of the world.* Marcus’s voice echoed in her memory, talking about the Seychelles, the Amazon, the far-flung and exotic. That was her brand. The woman who went to the other side of the world. But this man, with his scruffy dog and his quiet wisdom, had just articulated a truth she had been circling without knowing it. The adventure wasn't the destination. It was the seeing. And she had forgotten how to see the things that were right in front of her.

“You’re right,” she said, and the words were full of a dawning realisation. “It’s right under your feet.”

The man smiled, seemingly pleased. “Well, on that profound note, the bladder on this one waits for no man.” He gave a gentle tug on the leash, and Pip scrambled to his feet, ready for the next leg of their journey. “Nice talking to you, miss.”

“You too,” Eleanor said, meaning it. She watched them go, the old man and his faithful terrier, two figures moving with steady, unhurried purpose. When they had disappeared behind a copse of trees, Eleanor looked down at her own feet, planted firmly on the gravel path. Her boots were muddy. It was the best feeling she’d had in six weeks. She reached into her pocket and her fingers closed around the hard plastic of Zara Stryker, Jungle Adventurer. *See?* Zara’s voice in her head was smug. *Told you. Boots on the ground.*

The walk home was different. She wasn’t fleeing the world anymore; she was moving through it. Her gaze was no longer fixed on the pavement but scanning the buildings, the alleyways, the faces of passers-by. She saw the ghost sign of a long-closed bakery faded on a brick wall, the intricate pattern of ironwork on a boot-scraper by a front door, the surprising blue of a delphinium defiantly blooming in a window box. It was a treasure hunt. St Albans wasn't a cage. It was a landscape, dense with stories, waiting to be explored. Back in her flat, the silence felt different. It was no longer the oppressive silence of emptiness, but the quiet of contemplation. The unhelpful white ceiling was still there, but she didn’t look at it. Instead, she walked into her study and pulled out a notebook and a pen. On the first clean page, she wrote, in firm, clear letters: *Vance’s Ventures: Verulamium.* It was absurd. It was small. It was for an audience of one. But for the first time since her world had dropped from the sky, it felt like a flight plan she could follow.The next morning, the light filtering through the blinds painted stripes across the living room floor. Eleanor woke on the sofa, a crick in her neck, the throw blanket tangled around her legs. For a brief, blissful moment, her mind was a blank slate. Then memory rushed in: the flight, the fear, Marcus, the walk, the man with the dog. She lay still, waiting for the familiar wave of anxiety to crest and break over her. It came, but it was different. It was a ripple, not a tsunami. She sat up and her eyes went, not to the ceiling, but to the coffee table where the notebook lay open. *Vance’s Ventures: Verulamium.* In the cold light of day, it looked both childish and profound. It was a declaration of intent, a joke, and a lifeline, all written in a single line of ink.

Her routine for the past six weeks had been a study in minimalism: wake, drift, worry, sleep. Today, she found herself with a purpose, however small and self-assigned. After a shower that felt less like a chore and more like a preparation, she went to her study. The room, which had felt like a museum of a dead woman's life, now seemed like an unlocked arsenal. Her fingers ghosted over the spines of books on the Amazon, on the Silk Road, on the history of Polynesian navigation. She felt a pang, not of fear, but of a dull, wistful ache, like remembering a lover she had parted with on bad terms. Deliberately, she turned away from them and scanned the lower shelves, the neglected corner dedicated to Great Britain. Tucked between a guide to the Cornish coast and a history of London’s docklands, she found what she was looking for: a slim, academic-looking volume titled *Roman Verulamium: A City and its People*, and a fold-out Ordnance Survey map of Hertfordshire, its creases worn and soft. She spread the map out on her desk, its familiar greens and browns a comforting sight. The sprawling shape of modern St Albans was laid over the fainter, more ghostly outlines of the Roman city. For the first time in years, she was planning an expedition where the primary mode of transport was her own two feet. She packed a small rucksack: the book, the map, her notebook, a pen that didn't smudge, and the small, heavy digital camera she used to use for personal snaps before every moment became a potential piece of B-roll footage. As a final thought, she filled a thermos with strong tea, the way her dad used to on their weekend hikes. It felt like an act of profound self-care. Before leaving, she retrieved Zara from the study desk and zipped her securely into the rucksack’s side pocket, a tiny stowaway on this new, miniature venture.

The walk back to the park was a different experience from the day before. Her steps were firm, her head was up. She was no longer just a convalescent taking the air; she was on assignment. She navigated the streets with a new focus, her brain automatically cataloguing details. The Tudor-revival pub on the corner wasn’t just a pub; it was a landmark, a point on her internal map. The narrow alleyway she’d hurried past yesterday was now ‘Sumpter Yard’, and she made a mental note to find out who or what a Sumpter was. She was recoding her home from a place of confinement into a territory to be charted. Her destination today was specific: the Roman Theatre, a short walk from the main park. It was a place she had filmed a two-minute segment for a domestic travel show years ago, a breezy, superficial piece about ‘taking a trip back in time’. She barely remembered it.

Paying the modest entrance fee at the small wooden kiosk felt wonderfully anonymous. She was just another tourist, a face in the trickle of visitors. The attendant, a young man with a stud in his eyebrow, handed her a ticket and a leaflet without a flicker of recognition. Unflappable Ellie Vance was truly gone, and Eleanor found she was grateful for the invisibility. She walked down a gravel path and there it was. Not a grand Colosseum, but an intimate, bowl-like space, its tiered seating now gentle grassy banks rising from a circular stage area. The original flint-and-tile walls stood only a few feet high in most places, skeletal remains hinting at the structure that once was. It was quiet, the only sound the rustle of the wind in the tall trees that ringed the site and the distant laughter of children in a nearby playground. She stood in the centre of what would have been the orchestra, the focal point of thousands of eyes, two millennia ago. The irony was not lost on her. Her entire career had been a performance, and she had run away from the stage. Now here she was, standing on a much older one, with no audience but the ghosts. *Bit of a comedown from prime time, El,* Zara’s voice commented dryly from her pocket. *Still, the acoustics aren’t bad. And no one’s going to ask you to eat a bug.*

Eleanor smiled and found a spot on the highest grassy tier, giving her a commanding view of the whole theatre. She opened her rucksack, took out the thermos, and poured a cup of steaming tea. The warmth spread through her hands. This was a world away from a production assistant handing her a lukewarm bottle of water between takes. She opened her notebook. For a moment, pen hovered over paper, the old pressure to be witty, engaging, and concise seizing her up. Then she remembered. This wasn't for Marcus or the network. This was for her. She started to write, not a script, but a description. *The theatre doesn’t feel dead. The grass is too green for that. It feels like it’s sleeping. The flint walls are like the exposed bones of a whale, washed up and reclaimed by the land. You can feel the intention of the space – a place for people to gather, to be told a story.* She sketched a rough layout, noting where the entrances were, the position of the stage, the way the whole structure was dug into the hillside, using the landscape instead of fighting it. She was so engrossed, she barely noticed the thin white line etching itself across the high, grey sky.

It was the sound that caught her first. Not the guttural roar of a plane in trouble, but the faint, high-pitched hum of a commercial jetliner at cruising altitude, a sound that had once been the background music to her life. Her head snapped up. There it was, a tiny silver crucifix catching the sun above the clouds, moving with serene, implacable speed towards the eastern horizon. Her breath hitched. The thermos cup trembled in her hand, scalding tea sloshing over her fingers. The ground, which had felt so solid, suddenly seemed to drop away by an inch. Her heart hammered against her ribs, a frantic, trapped bird. The memory rose, unbidden and visceral: the lurch, the groan of metal, the absolute certainty of death. The sunny, peaceful theatre vanished, replaced by the cramped, terrifying confines of her airline seat. *It’s just a plane,* she told herself, her voice a silent scream in her head. *It’s thirty thousand feet up. It’s not falling.* But the primal part of her brain, the part that had been permanently rewired over the Andes, didn’t listen to logic. It only knew terror. She squeezed her eyes shut, her knuckles white as she gripped the thermos. *Don't you dare,* Zara’s voice snapped, sharp and commanding. *Don’t you let that tin can win. Look at the wall. The Roman one. The one that’s been here for two thousand years. Touch it.* Her eyes flew open. She scrambled down the grassy bank to the nearest section of ruined wall and pressed both her palms flat against the cold, rough flint. She focused on the feeling: the sharp edges, the sandy mortar, the deep, unmoving cold of the earth. She breathed in the scent of damp stone and soil. Grounded. She was grounded. Slowly, the frantic drumming in her chest began to subside. The world swam back into focus. The jet was gone. The only things moving were the leaves on the trees. She stayed there for a full minute, leaning against the ancient wall as if it were the only thing holding her upright. Then, shakily, she walked back to her spot, sat down, and picked up her pen. Her hand was trembling, but she forced it to move. *A plane flew over,* she wrote. *I thought I was going to fall apart. I didn't.*The tremor in her hand subsided into a dull ache. Eleanor didn't pack up and flee. That would have been a victory for the fear, a confirmation that it still owned her. Instead, she performed a small, deliberate ritual of defiance. She poured the last of the tea from her thermos into the cup, her movements consciously steady. She drank it slowly, letting the warmth seep into her, a counter-current to the icy chill that had threatened to engulf her. She looked at the last line she had written: *I thought I was going to fall apart. I didn't.* It was the most honest thing she had written in years. She picked up the pen again, and below that line, she added: *The wall was colder than the fear.* It wasn't poetry, but it was true, and the truth felt like a handhold on a sheer cliff face. She spent another hour at the theatre, reading from her book, making notes, comparing the academic descriptions to the quiet reality in front of her. She was a scholar, not a star. The work was slow and methodical and deeply, wonderfully boring.

The journey back to her flat was a mapping expedition. Her phone stayed in her pocket. She relied instead on the Ordnance Survey map, unfolding it at a street corner to check her position, a tangible link between her and the city. She took a different route, a winding path through the formal Victorian gardens behind the main park. She paused to read the dedication on a forgotten water fountain and spent five minutes studying the strange, almost alien-looking seed pods of a monkey puzzle tree. She was collecting data, filling the empty spaces in her mind—once occupied by flight schedules and currency conversions—with the texture and detail of a single square mile. She clutched the strap of her bag, the hard outline of her notebook a reassuring pressure against her side, and walked through the revolving doors.

The radio studio was a small, soundless room, a padded cell designed for the perfect capture of the human voice. It smelled of clean electronics and faint, stale coffee. Jamila Chowdhury greeted her with a firm handshake and a warm, professional smile. She was exactly as her voice on the radio suggested: sharp, focused, and exuding an air of calm intelligence. “Thank you for coming in, Eleanor,” she said. “We’ll have about eight minutes. I’ll start by setting the context, then I’ll bring you in. Just speak as you would to a friend over coffee. A very large coffee with several million people listening in.” The joke was meant to be disarming, but it only served to heighten the terrifying reality of the situation. Eleanor sat opposite her, a large, foam-covered microphone between them. A technician gave her a thumbs-up from behind a pane of glass. The 'On Air' light glowed a sudden, furious red.

“The rise of the creator economy has raised complex new questions about ownership, corporate power, and the relationship between an artist and their audience,” Jamila’s voice began, smooth and authoritative. “A fascinating case study has emerged in recent weeks around the former travel presenter Eleanor Vance…” Eleanor listened, her heart pounding a frantic rhythm against her ribs. She was being introduced, contextualised, turned into a topic for national debate. “Eleanor Vance joins me now in the studio. Eleanor, your former employers claim that this is a straightforward case of breach of contract. You claim it is an act of what you’ve called ‘colonisation’. Can you explain what you mean by that?”

Eleanor took a breath, the sound impossibly loud in her own ears. She looked at the microphone as if it were a hostile creature. She opened her mouth to speak, and the voice that came out was quiet, steady, and utterly her own. “Good morning, Jamila. I think it comes down to a simple question: when a contract ends, who owns the goodwill? My old career was built on a brand, and that brand was owned by the network. I understand that. But when I started again, from nothing, in my flat in St Albans, I wasn’t trading on that brand. I was building something new, based on a different set of values. The support I’ve received isn’t from fans of a TV show. It’s from a community of people who are interested in Roman bricks and the stories our landscape has to tell. The network sees that support as an ‘asset’ to be seized, like an office chair. I see it as a conversation. And you can’t put a lien on a conversation.” The words, rehearsed in her notebook, felt solid and true when spoken aloud. She was no longer afraid. She was simply testifying.

Jamila nodded, her expression unreadable. “But they would argue they invested millions in building your public profile. Don’t they have a right to recoup their losses when you walk away from your contractual obligations?”

“They have a right to sue me for breach of contract. I have never disputed that,” Eleanor said calmly. “That is the closing of an old account. But laying claim to the income from my new project is something different. It’s an attempt to ensure that anyone who leaves their system can never build anything for themselves. It’s a message that they own not just your work, but your ability to ever work again. My new project, ‘Grounded’, is about discovering the value in things the world has forgotten. My patrons are supporting that idea. To divert their support back to the very system that values profit above all else would be a profound betrayal of the trust they’ve placed in me. It would be like letting the Romans bill the Saxons for the stones they scavenged to build their new churches.”

The historical analogy, drawn from her hours in the Abbey, landed with a quiet resonance in the soundproofed room. She saw a flicker of genuine interest in Jamila’s eyes. This was the language of her new world, and it was holding its own in the heart of the old one. The eight minutes flew by in a blur of intense, focused conversation. Eleanor spoke of the bumps in the field, of the need for quieter, slower media, of a community built on shared curiosity rather than celebrity worship. She never raised her voice. She never once sounded like a victim. She sounded like a woman who had discovered something of immense value and was now calmly, stubbornly defending it.

When the interview was over, when the red light blinked off and the sound of the studio’s air conditioning returned, a profound silence fell between the two women. Jamila took off her headphones and looked at Eleanor, a slow, thoughtful smile spreading across her face. “Thank you, Eleanor,” she said, her voice dropping from its broadcast perfection to a more personal tone. “That was… very good indeed.” The producer in the control room gave her an enthusiastic thumbs-up. Eleanor just nodded, unable to speak, a wave of exhaustion and adrenaline washing over her. She had done it. She had walked into the Forum, spoken her truth, and walked out on her own two feet. The journey back to St Albans was a dream. She had no idea what the consequences of her testimony would be. She only knew that she had dropped another stone into the well, and this one had been a boulder. The ripples were just beginning to spread.The journey back from London was an exercise in deliberate disconnection. Eleanor sat on the train, her forehead pressed against the cool glass of the window, and watched the blur of the suburbs give way to the green fields of Hertfordshire. She did not open her phone. She did not check for reactions or messages. She had stepped out of the river of noise and now, on its banks, she needed a moment of stillness before she could even begin to assess whether she had been carried to safety or swept further out to sea. The flat, when she returned to it, was a silent, welcoming haven. The air was cool and still. Her notebooks were on the desk, her corkboard was on the wall, and the unhelpful white ceiling was exactly where she had left it. It was the most beautiful sight in the world. For an hour, she did nothing. She made a pot of tea and sat on her sofa, watching the dust motes dance in the afternoon light, simply inhabiting the quiet space she had fought for. She was breathing her own air again.

When she finally felt grounded enough to face the consequences of her testimony, she did so with a sense of calm resolve. She opened her laptop, her tea growing cold beside her. The screen lit up, and the digital world rushed in like a tidal wave. Her website, Grounded.co.uk, had a new, stark banner across the top, placed there by Ben: **SITE TRAFFIC IS EXTREMELY HIGH. PLEASE BE PATIENT.** He had emailed her a single, frantic, triumphant line: “The servers are melting. I’ve had to upgrade the hosting package twice this morning. Whatever you said, Ellie, they heard you.” Her YouTube video, which had been sitting at a respectable thirty thousand views, had skyrocketed past half a million. The comment section was a roaring, unreadable torrent of support. The hashtag #HandsOffGrounded was the number one trending topic on UK Twitter.

She clicked over to her Patreon page, her new monthly income total scrolling upwards like a slot machine hitting a jackpot. Two thousand pounds a month. Four thousand. Five. It was an astonishing, terrifying number, a testament to the power of a story well told on a national platform. But it was the messages, not the money, that made her chest tighten. They were pouring in from all over the country, from all over the world. A group of archaeology students in Australia had taken up a collection. A retired lawyer in Scotland had posted a long, detailed analysis of the network’s legal position, calling it “an act of corporate bastardry of the highest order.” A primary school teacher in Cornwall wrote that her class had listened to the interview and were now doing a project on their local tin mines. “You’ve taught them that history isn’t just in books,” she wrote. “It’s under their feet. Thank you.” Eleanor felt a profound, humbling sense of responsibility. She had accidentally become the custodian of a movement, the voice for a quiet but deeply felt dissatisfaction with the way the world was.

Her inbox was a war zone. Dozens of journalists, from national newspapers to international television networks, were clamouring for an interview. A literary agent wanted to talk about a book deal. A production company that specialised in “prestige factual” programming wanted to discuss a broadcast version of ‘Grounded’. It was the life she had just escaped, rushing back to her on a tidal wave of opportunity, but this time, it was on her terms. She stared at the deluge of offers, the dizzying array of possibilities, and felt a familiar vertigo. It would be so easy to say yes, to ride this wave, to sign the deals and hire a team and become ‘Ellie Vance, Independent Media Mogul’. But that was just another kind of cage, a more gilded one, perhaps, but a cage nonetheless. She took a deep breath, composed a single, simple message, and posted it across all her platforms.

*“Thank you, all of you, for your incredible support. I am overwhelmed and deeply grateful. I have been invited to tell my story in many places, but I have already testified. The work now is not to talk, but to build. My focus remains on this community and on the next episode of Grounded. The best way to prove that a different way is possible is to walk it. Thank you for walking it with me. E.”*

It was a statement of intent, a quiet refusal of the circus. It was a promise to her community that she would not be distracted, that she would honour the principle they were all fighting for. The response was a second wave of support, this time deeper, more respectful. They understood. They were not following a celebrity; they were supporting a project. Having posted her message, she logged out of her email and her social media, severing the connection to the storm. She went back to her corkboard and looked at her notes for her next episode, a planned exploration of the ancient Icknield Way. It was a tangible, grounding task in a world that had suddenly become terrifyingly abstract.

The phone call came that evening. The number was blocked. For a moment, she considered not answering, but she knew she couldn’t hide forever. “Hello?” she said, her voice steady.
There was a pause, a faint electronic hiss. Then a voice she knew all too well, a voice she had been dreading and expecting. “Ellie-cat.” It was Marcus. But the voice was utterly changed. The slick, professional bonhomie was gone. The exasperated snap was gone. What was left was a strained, weary husk. He sounded like a man who had not slept in three days.
“Marcus,” she replied, her tone flat and cold.
“Listen, Ellie,” he began, and she could hear the effort it was taking him to keep his voice even. “We need to talk. Off the record. Just you and me.”
“I think we’re well past that,” she said.
“No, please,” he said, and the note of desperation in his voice was unmistakable. “You have no idea what it’s like here. The phones haven’t stopped ringing. Legal is in meltdown. The board is furious. That stunt you pulled on the *Today* programme… that was a nuclear option, Ellie. You’ve torched the village.”
“I didn’t start the fire, Marcus. I just pointed out that it was burning.”
He let out a long, ragged sigh. “Look, I’m not calling to argue. I’m calling with an offer. A way to put this all to bed. The network is prepared to… adjust its position.”
Eleanor waited, saying nothing.
“Okay,” he said, taking a breath. “Here it is. We drop the claim. The whole thing. The two-hundred-and-forty-seven grand, the claim on your little… project… all of it. It goes away. Wiped clean.”
The offer was so sudden, so total, that it left her momentarily speechless. Total victory. Everything she had been fighting for. “In exchange for what?” she asked, her voice sharp with suspicion.
“In exchange for a joint statement,” he said, his voice regaining a fraction of its old, slick rhythm as he switched into deal-making mode. “Something simple. We say there was a misunderstanding, a miscommunication between legal departments during a complex contractual negotiation. We say we fully support your new creative direction and wish you the best. You say you regret the public nature of the dispute and confirm that the network has acted in good faith to resolve it. We both walk away looking reasonable. You get your freedom, we get the dogs called off. Everyone wins.”
Eleanor was silent, letting the proposal sink in. It was a good deal. It was a perfect corporate solution. It was a clean, elegant lie. A misunderstanding. Good faith. All she had to do was sign her name to it, and the terror, the debt, the threat that had haunted her for months would simply vanish. The cage door was wide open. But the price of walking through it was to agree that the cage had never really been there in the first place. She thought of Aris’s words: *the health of the Republic*. She thought of the teacher in Cornwall, the students in Australia, the thousands of people who had rallied not just to her, but to the principle she now represented. To accept this deal would be to betray them all. It would be to agree that it had all just been a personal spat, a melodrama, just as Marcus had originally claimed.
“No,” she said. The word was quiet, but it was absolute.
Marcus was silent for a beat, stunned. “What? Ellie, don’t be insane. This is a get-out-of-jail-free card. Take the win.”
“It’s not a win, Marcus. It’s a compromise. And I’m done with those. You’re not offering a solution. You’re offering a gag order disguised as a press release. You want me to help you pretend this never happened.”
“Of course we want to pretend it never happened!” he snapped, his composure finally cracking. “It’s a PR catastrophe! What do you want, Ellie? Blood?”
“No,” she said again, a strange, calm certainty settling over her. She knew, in that instant, exactly what she wanted. It was no longer just about being left alone. It was about ensuring that this could not happen to anyone else. “I want you to issue a public statement. A unilateral one. Admitting that attempting to seize income from a creator’s independent crowdfunding is an unacceptable and unethical practice. I want you to announce a formal review of your standard contracts to remove any such clauses in the future. And then, I want the network to make a substantial donation to the British Archaeological Trust, as a gesture of goodwill to the community you tried to damage.” She paused, letting the weight of her demands land. “You do that, and I will consider the matter resolved.”
There was a long, strangled silence on the other end of the line. She could almost hear the blood draining from Marcus’s face. She had not just refused his deal. She had dictated terms. She had demanded not just a retreat, but a public surrender and reparations.
“You,” he said finally, his voice a choked whisper of disbelief and rage, “are out of your mind.”
“No, Marcus,” Eleanor replied, a small, wry smile touching her lips for the first time. “For the first time in a very long time, I am perfectly sane. You have my terms. The Forum awaits your response.” And with a quiet click, she ended the call, leaving her old producer holding the smoking ruins of his perfect, elegant lie. She stood in the centre of her small living room, the silence of the flat now feeling not like an absence, but like a presence. It was the sound of solid ground beneath her feet.

parts.text:
The ceiling was an unhelpful shade of white. A flat, expansive nothing that stretched from one corniced edge to the other, offering precisely zero solutions to the problem of being Eleanor Vance. It had been her primary confidante for the past six weeks, this ceiling. It had listened to her silent screams, absorbed the frantic thumping of her heart, and watched, dispassionately, as her world shrank from the circumference of the globe to the four walls of a two-bedroom flat overlooking the perpetual traffic of St Peter's Street.

The last time she’d been in the air, the world had tried to shake her out of it. Like a dog with a rat. The flight from Cusco to Lima. It was supposed to be routine, a little puddle-jumper between filming segments for her show, *Vance’s Ventures*. She was the jaunty, unflappable presenter who could charm a snake in Marrakech or navigate the floating markets of the Mekong Delta with a single, winning smile. Unflappable Eleanor Vance. The woman who could eat a witchetty grub without flinching. That woman was dead. She’d died somewhere over the Andes, at thirty-seven thousand feet, during a bout of turbulence so violent it had thrown a flight attendant into the overhead lockers.

It wasn't the shaking, not really. It was the sound. A deep, guttural groan from the belly of the aircraft, a sound of metal being asked to do something it was never designed to do. And then the drop. Not a dip, not a lurch, but a sickening, stomach-hollowing plunge into thin air, a freefall that lasted only a few seconds but had permanently rewired her brain. In those seconds, she had known, with a certainty that eclipsed all other knowledge, that she was going to die. The universe had contracted to the dimensions of her seat, to the frantic grip of her own hands on the armrests, the plastic sweating against her palms. She hadn't screamed. She had simply stopped breathing, her body a rigid vessel of pure, distilled terror. When the plane finally stabilised, when the captain’s absurdly calm voice crackled over the intercom apologising for the “spot of weather,” a woman a few rows ahead had begun to weep. A low, animal sound of pure relief. Eleanor had just sat there, staring at the back of the seat in front of her, a stranger in her own body.

Now, the loudest sound was the hum of the fridge and the distant, mournful cry of a siren. St Albans. Home. It had always been her anchor, the quiet, historic city she returned to after her whirlwind trips. The Roman walls of Verulamium, the ancient stones of the Abbey, the Saturday market teeming with life. It was meant to be a sanctuary. It had become a cage. Her passport sat in a drawer, gathering dust like a relic from a forgotten civilization. Her suitcase, usually in a state of semi-permanent packing, was shoved in the back of a wardrobe, zipped shut on a life she no longer knew how to lead.

Her phone buzzed on the coffee table, a frantic, angry vibration against the wood. The screen lit up with a name that made her stomach clench. *Marcus.* Of course. She watched it vibrate, a small black harbinger of doom. He’d been patient for the first two weeks, sympathetic for the third, and was now entering a phase of barely-concealed exasperation. She let it go to voicemail, the silence that followed the buzzing somehow more accusatory than the noise itself. A minute later, it buzzed again. A text.

*Ellie, pick up. We HAVE to talk. The network is asking about the Seychelles shoot.*

The Seychelles. Just the word made her feel dizzy. An archipelago of islands floating in an endless expanse of blue. Blue water. Blue sky. And the only way to get there was in a pressurised metal tube, a coffin with wings. She squeezed her eyes shut, the memory of the drop rising in her throat like bile. The phone rang again, insistent. This time, she knew he wouldn't give up. With a sigh that seemed to pull up stones from the bottom of her soul, she answered.

"Marcus."

"Ellie-cat! Thank God. I was about to send a search party. Are you alright? You sound like you're at the bottom of a well." His voice was a slick, professional performance of concern.

"I'm fine, Marcus. Just… tired."

"Tired? Darling, you've had six weeks off. Most people would be climbing the walls with boredom. I'm sure St Albans is lovely, all that history, but it’s not exactly the Amazon, is it?" He chuckled, a dry, rustling sound. "Listen, about the Seychelles. Production has the filming permits sorted, the crew is on standby. We're looking at a departure in two weeks. A nice, gentle flight. Direct. Emirates. They have those lovely little washbags, even in premium economy."

Eleanor stared at her ceiling. The unhelpful, stupidly white ceiling. "I can't." The words were small, brittle things.

A pause on the other end of the line. The bonhomie in his voice evaporated, replaced by a cold, hard edge. "What do you mean, you can't? Eleanor, this is the flagship series. *Vance's Ventures: Islands in the Sun*. It's your name on the tin. They've already run the promos."

"I mean I can't get on the plane, Marcus." She heard the tremor in her own voice and hated it. "I told you. After the Peru flight…"

"Oh, for heaven's sake," he snapped, all pretence gone. "It was a bit of turbulence! It happens. You fly a hundred times a year, Ellie. You can’t let one bumpy ride derail your entire career. It's unprofessional."

Unprofessional. The word landed like a slap. She, who had waded through leech-infested waters, who had slept in hammocks in jungles alive with things that bite, who had smiled for the camera while nursing a bout of dysentery that would have felled a lesser mortal. Unprofessional.

"It wasn't a bumpy ride," she said, her voice dangerously quiet. "You weren't there."

"Well, I'm here now, trying to salvage your career!" he shot back. "Do you have any idea how much money is riding on this? The sponsors, the network… they're not going to wait forever. There are a hundred other presenters who would kill for this gig. That girl who does the weekend weather, Chloe something, she's been calling me. Non-stop."

A hot spike of anger, sharp and clean, cut through the fog of fear. Chloe-something. A perky blonde with a surgically-enhanced smile and the intellectual depth of a puddle. "Then give it to Chloe," she said, the words tasting like poison.

"Don't be ridiculous," Marcus hissed. "You're the brand. 'Unflappable Ellie Vance'. We just need to get you back on the horse. Have you tried anything? Hypnotherapy? Gin? A nice, strong sedative?"

"I'm not getting on the plane, Marcus."

Another silence, this one long and cold and full of the sound of contracts being mentally torn up. "Right," he said finally. His voice was flat. "I see. Well. When you've decided to stop this… melodrama… give me a call. But don't leave it too long, Ellie. The world moves on. Even if you don't."

The line went dead. Eleanor held the phone to her ear for a moment longer, listening to the dial tone. Melodrama. He thought this was a choice. A fit of pique. He had no concept of the sheer, primal terror that now lived in her, a cold, heavy parasite curled around her spine. She threw the phone onto the sofa, the bounce unsatisfyingly soft. The flat was silent again, but the silence was different now. It was filled with Marcus’s words, with the phantom calls of Chloe-something, with the tick-tock of her career bleeding out on the beige carpet.

She stood up and walked, aimlessly at first, her bare feet cold on the floorboards. She drifted from the living room into her small study, a room that was once her pride and joy. It was lined with bookshelves groaning under the weight of travel guides, maps, and histories of far-flung places. On one shelf, nestled between a chunk of volcanic rock from Iceland and a hand-carved mask from Papua New Guinea, stood Zara.

Zara was four inches tall, moulded from hard, unyielding plastic, with articulated joints at her shoulders, elbows, and knees. She wore khaki shorts, sturdy-looking boots, and a ridiculously determined expression on her tiny, painted face. Her official name, according to the packaging Eleanor had thrown out years ago, was 'Zara Stryker, Jungle Adventurer'. She came with a plastic machete and a pair of binoculars that didn’t work. Eleanor’s step-father had given her the action figure as a joke gift for her tenth birthday, a "sidekick" for the tomboy who was always climbing trees and scraping her knees. Zara had been her silent co-pilot ever since, a tiny mascot who had lived in her backpack through two dozen countries. Now, she was the only one left who seemed to understand.

Eleanor picked her up. The plastic was cool and solid in her hand. She positioned Zara on the edge of the desk, her little plastic boots dangling over the precipice.

"Well," Eleanor said to the empty room, her voice hoarse. "He thinks it's melodrama."

She waited, a habit she'd never quite broken. In her head, a voice that was hers but not hers, a voice that was braver and more certain, supplied the response. Zara's voice. *Marcus is a suit, El. He thinks a stiff upper lip is a substitute for a spine. What does a desk jockey know about the sky trying to eat you?*

A small, wry smile touched Eleanor’s lips. "He wants to give my show to Chloe-something from the weather."

*Let him,* Zara’s voice shot back, full of bravado. *Her idea of an adventure is finding a parking space at Brent Cross. Good riddance. We don't need their tin can aeroplane anyway. The greatest discoveries aren't made at thirty-seven thousand feet. They're made on the ground. With your boots on.*

Eleanor turned the tiny figure over in her fingers. Zara's painted-on eyes stared back, fierce and uncomplicated. She was right, of course. Or the part of Eleanor's brain that she'd outsourced to a plastic doll was right. The anger from Marcus's call was still there, a hot coal in her chest, and Zara's imagined defiance was fanning it into a small, flickering flame. Melodrama. Unprofessional. Fine. She walked back into the living room, scooped up her phone, and with a decisive tap of her thumb, deleted Marcus’s entire call history and message thread. It was a small, petty act, but it felt like taking a breath after being held underwater. She couldn’t fly. That was a fact, hard and immovable as the Abbey down the street. But maybe, just maybe, she didn’t have to stay grounded.

*Boots on the ground.* The thought was so clear, it was almost a sound. It echoed in the new, Marcus-less silence of the flat. For weeks, she had been floating, untethered from her own life, adrift in an ocean of anxiety with only the white ceiling for a sky. Now, an anchor had dropped. It wasn't a solution, not a cure, but it was a point of contact with something solid. She looked down at her bare feet, pale against the dark wood of the floor. She had walked on scorching desert sands and treacherous mountain paths in her career, yet for the past six weeks, the journey from the sofa to the kettle had felt like an expedition. The idea was absurd, terrifying, and utterly necessary. She had to go out.

The decision was a spark, but the execution was wading through mud. A dozen excuses presented themselves immediately. It was late afternoon, it might rain, she hadn't showered, what would she even do out there? The litany of inertia was a familiar, cloying song. She walked to the window and looked down at the street. Cars crawled past, people with shopping bags and determined expressions moved along the pavement, each on their own trajectory, each grounded in the simple, unthinking business of living. They weren't falling from the sky. They were just walking down the street. It looked like the most profound and enviable magic trick she had ever seen. She felt a pang of jealousy so sharp it almost stole her breath. That was the feeling that finally propelled her into motion. Jealousy was better than terror. It was an active, hungry emotion.

In her bedroom, she ignored the wardrobe with its ghost-filled suitcase and instead pulled open a drawer of clothes she hadn't touched since her return. Not the quick-dry, multi-pocketed trousers of her television persona, but a simple pair of jeans. She pulled on a jumper, the soft wool a comforting weight on her shoulders. The final, most important step was footwear. Tucked away under a pile of discarded magazines were her old walking boots. Not the high-tech, brightly-coloured ones the show’s sponsors provided, but a scuffed, well-worn leather pair that had moulded to her feet over a decade of weekend hikes in the Peak District and the Scottish Highlands, long before *Vance’s Ventures* was even a concept. Sliding her feet into them felt like a homecoming. Before she left the study, she paused, then decisively plucked Zara from the desk and slipped the tiny adventurer into her jacket pocket. The hard plastic was a reassuring lump against her hip.

The front door was the final boss. Her hand hovered over the latch, the familiar shape of it suddenly alien. Outside was the world. The big, loud, unpredictable world that contained noise and strangers and open skies. The same sky she had plummeted through. Her heart began to do its familiar frantic drum solo against her ribs. *It's just a street, El,* Zara’s voice piped up in her head, impatient and practical. *Not the summit of K2. You’re not going to get vertigo from the kerb. Get a grip.* Eleanor took a breath, turned the lock, and pulled the door open. The air that hit her was cool and damp, carrying the scent of traffic fumes and rain-soaked stone. The muted hum of the city she’d heard through double-glazing was now a complex symphony of distinct sounds: the squeal of a bus's brakes, the distant chime of the Abbey clock, the murmur of conversation from people passing by. It was overwhelming, a sensory flood after the sterile quiet of the flat.

She took a step out onto the landing, then another down the communal stairs, each footfall on the worn carpet a conscious, deliberate act. When she finally pushed open the heavy main door and stepped onto the pavement of St Peter's Street, she had to stop for a moment, blinking in the grey afternoon light. The sky above was a blanket of soft, uniform cloud, an altogether more helpful shade of grey than the white of her ceiling. There were no gaping expanses of blue, no dizzying heights, just a low, comforting lid on the world. She turned away from the main road, towards the quieter lanes that led to the park. Her walk was hesitant at first, her gaze fixed on the pavement in front of her as if she were navigating a crevasse. But as she moved, a forgotten rhythm began to return to her limbs. She started to look up, to notice things. The intricate brickwork on a Georgian townhouse, a flash of startling green from a parakeet in a tree, the weathered face of a stone gargoyle peering down from a church roof. This was what she did. This was who she was. She was an observer, a collector of details. She had just forgotten how to do it without a camera crew in tow. The journey was only ten minutes, but it felt like crossing a continent. When the ancient Roman wall that bordered Verulamium Park rose up at the end of the lane, solid and implacable, Eleanor stopped. It had stood here for almost two thousand years. It had seen empires rise and fall. It hadn’t fallen out of the sky. She reached out and pressed her palm against the cold, flint-studded surface. It was real. It was solid. And for the first time in six weeks, so was she.

The flint was rough under her palm, a mosaic of jagged edges cemented by time. Each stone was an individual, a story, but together they formed a defence that had stood against weather and war. Eleanor traced the line of mortar with her finger, feeling the grit and the cold. She had built her own walls these past weeks, but they were smooth and white and offered no purchase. They were meant to keep the world out, but had only succeeded in trapping her in. This wall was different. It was part of the world, defining a space without imprisoning it.

Following its curve, she walked deeper into the park. The grass was a deep, damp green, softened by the day’s drizzle. A flock of Canada geese paraded near the edge of the lake, honking with self-important indignation as a toddler ran a little too close. The sound was raucous and alive, a world away from the metallic groans of an aeroplane in distress. For her show, she would have framed this shot with the Abbey spire in the background, perhaps getting a low angle to make the geese seem more formidable, narrating a witty voiceover about territorial disputes in the Home Counties. The instinct was still there, a ghost limb of her former profession, but today there was no crew, no shot list, no pressure to perform. There was just the watching.

She found an empty bench facing the water, its wooden slats slick with rain. She sat, placing her hands on her knees, feeling the rough texture of her jeans. She watched a pair of coots paddle in frantic, neurotic circles. She watched a man in a high-vis jacket methodically spearing litter into a black bag. She watched a young couple huddle together under a single, enormous umbrella, their quiet laughter carrying across the water. It was all so profoundly, beautifully ordinary. These people were not thinking about the physics of lift or the tensile strength of a fuselage. Their worlds were not shrinking; they were expanding with every shared joke, every step taken, every mundane task completed. The jealousy she’d felt earlier returned, but it was less sharp now, diluted with a strange sense of wonder.

A wet nose nudged insistently against her hand. Eleanor startled, looking down into the intelligent, whiskery face of a border terrier. The dog’s tail gave a hopeful thump-thump-thump against the leg of the bench.

“Oi, Pip! Leave the lady alone. You’re harassing the public.” The voice was a gravelly, good-natured rumble. An elderly man in a tweed flat cap and a well-worn Barbour jacket shuffled towards them, a leash coiled in his hand. He had a kind, crinkled face and eyes the same pale grey as the sky. “Sorry about him. He has no sense of personal space. Thinks everyone he meets is a long-lost friend with a pocket full of biscuits.”

“It’s alright,” Eleanor said, surprised at how steady her voice sounded. She gave the terrier, Pip, a scratch behind the ears. His fur was wiry and coarse. “He’s very charming.”

“He’s a menace,” the man said with obvious affection, sitting down at the other end of the bench with a slight groan. “Just taking the old boy for his constitutional. We do this every day, rain or shine. Don’t we, Pip?” The dog, having received his quota of affection, settled at the man’s feet with a contented sigh. They sat in a comfortable silence for a moment, two strangers and a dog watching the coots. “It’s a good day for it,” the man said eventually. “Quiet. The park feels like it can breathe a bit, after the weekend.”

“Yes,” Eleanor agreed. “It’s peaceful.”

“You new to St Albans?” he asked, his curiosity gentle. “Don’t think I’ve seen you on our patrol route before.”

The question hung in the air. Was she new? She had owned her flat for five years, but it had only ever been a base camp. She knew the fastest route to Heathrow better than she knew the winding medieval lanes behind the cathedral. “No,” she said slowly. “I’ve lived here a while. Just… haven’t been out much lately.”

The man just nodded, accepting the statement without question or judgment. He pointed with his chin towards the half-excavated remains of a Roman townhouse visible across the grass. “Funny, isn’t it? People come from all over the world to see a few old walls and a bit of floor. But the people who live here, we walk past it every day and barely give it a glance. It’s just the park.” He chuckled to himself. “Took my grandson the other week. He was more interested in the ice cream van. But I told him, I said, ‘Imagine being a Roman, waking up right here. What would you see? No Abbey, no traffic. Just fields and trees and the road to Londinium.’ You don’t have to go to the other side of the world to find a different country. Sometimes it’s just under your feet.”

The words struck Eleanor with the force of a physical blow. *You don’t have to go to the other side of the world.* Marcus’s voice echoed in her memory, talking about the Seychelles, the Amazon, the far-flung and exotic. That was her brand. The woman who went to the other side of the world. But this man, with his scruffy dog and his quiet wisdom, had just articulated a truth she had been circling without knowing it. The adventure wasn't the destination. It was the seeing. And she had forgotten how to see the things that were right in front of her.

“You’re right,” she said, and the words were full of a dawning realisation. “It’s right under your feet.”

The man smiled, seemingly pleased. “Well, on that profound note, the bladder on this one waits for no man.” He gave a gentle tug on the leash, and Pip scrambled to his feet, ready for the next leg of their journey. “Nice talking to you, miss.”

“You too,” Eleanor said, meaning it. She watched them go, the old man and his faithful terrier, two figures moving with steady, unhurried purpose. When they had disappeared behind a copse of trees, Eleanor looked down at her own feet, planted firmly on the gravel path. Her boots were muddy. It was the best feeling she’d had in six weeks. She reached into her pocket and her fingers closed around the hard plastic of Zara Stryker, Jungle Adventurer. *See?* Zara’s voice in her head was smug. *Told you. Boots on the ground.*

The walk home was different. She wasn’t fleeing the world anymore; she was moving through it. Her gaze was no longer fixed on the pavement but scanning the buildings, the alleyways, the faces of passers-by. She saw the ghost sign of a long-closed bakery faded on a brick wall, the intricate pattern of ironwork on a boot-scraper by a front door, the surprising blue of a delphinium defiantly blooming in a window box. It was a treasure hunt. St Albans wasn't a cage. It was a landscape, dense with stories, waiting to be explored. Back in her flat, the silence felt different. It was no longer the oppressive silence of emptiness, but the quiet of contemplation. The unhelpful white ceiling was still there, but she didn’t look at it. Instead, she walked into her study and pulled out a notebook and a pen. On the first clean page, she wrote, in firm, clear letters: *Vance’s Ventures: Verulamium.* It was absurd. It was small. It was for an audience of one. But for the first time since her world had dropped from the sky, it felt like a flight plan she could follow.

The next morning, the light filtering through the blinds painted stripes across the living room floor. Eleanor woke on the sofa, a crick in her neck, the throw blanket tangled around her legs. For a brief, blissful moment, her mind was a blank slate. Then memory rushed in: the flight, the fear, Marcus, the walk, the man with the dog. She lay still, waiting for the familiar wave of anxiety to crest and break over her. It came, but it was different. It was a ripple, not a tsunami. She sat up and her eyes went, not to the ceiling, but to the coffee table where the notebook lay open. *Vance’s Ventures: Verulamium.* In the cold light of day, it looked both childish and profound. It was a declaration of intent, a joke, and a lifeline, all written in a single line of ink.

Her routine for the past six weeks had been a study in minimalism: wake, drift, worry, sleep. Today, she found herself with a purpose, however small and self-assigned. After a shower that felt less like a chore and more like a preparation, she went to her study. The room, which had felt like a museum of a dead woman's life, now seemed like an unlocked arsenal. Her fingers ghosted over the spines of books on the Amazon, on the Silk Road, on the history of Polynesian navigation. She felt a pang, not of fear, but of a dull, wistful ache, like remembering a lover she had parted with on bad terms. Deliberately, she turned away from them and scanned the lower shelves, the neglected corner dedicated to Great Britain. Tucked between a guide to the Cornish coast and a history of London’s docklands, she found what she was looking for: a slim, academic-looking volume titled *Roman Verulamium: A City and its People*, and a fold-out Ordnance Survey map of Hertfordshire, its creases worn and soft. She spread the map out on her desk, its familiar greens and browns a comforting sight. The sprawling shape of modern St Albans was laid over the fainter, more ghostly outlines of the Roman city. For the first time in years, she was planning an expedition where the primary mode of transport was her own two feet. She packed a small rucksack: the book, the map, her notebook, a pen that didn't smudge, and the small, heavy digital camera she used to use for personal snaps before every moment became a potential piece of B-roll footage. As a final thought, she filled a thermos with strong tea, the way her dad used to on their weekend hikes. It felt like an act of profound self-care. Before leaving, she retrieved Zara from the study desk and zipped her securely into the rucksack’s side pocket, a tiny stowaway on this new, miniature venture.

The walk back to the park was a different experience from the day before. Her steps were firm, her head was up. She was no longer just a convalescent taking the air; she was on assignment. She navigated the streets with a new focus, her brain automatically cataloguing details. The Tudor-revival pub on the corner wasn’t just a pub; it was a landmark, a point on her internal map. The narrow alleyway she’d hurried past yesterday was now ‘Sumpter Yard’, and she made a mental note to find out who or what a Sumpter was. She was recoding her home from a place of confinement into a territory to be charted. Her destination today was specific: the Roman Theatre, a short walk from the main park. It was a place she had filmed a two-minute segment for a domestic travel show years ago, a breezy, superficial piece about ‘taking a trip back in time’. She barely remembered it.

Paying the modest entrance fee at the small wooden kiosk felt wonderfully anonymous. She was just another tourist, a face in the trickle of visitors. The attendant, a young man with a stud in his eyebrow, handed her a ticket and a leaflet without a flicker of recognition. Unflappable Ellie Vance was truly gone, and Eleanor found she was grateful for the invisibility. She walked down a gravel path and there it was. Not a grand Colosseum, but an intimate, bowl-like space, its tiered seating now gentle grassy banks rising from a circular stage area. The original flint-and-tile walls stood only a few feet high in most places, skeletal remains hinting at the structure that once was. It was quiet, the only sound the rustle of the wind in the tall trees that ringed the site and the distant laughter of children in a nearby playground. She stood in the centre of what would have been the orchestra, the focal point of thousands of eyes, two millennia ago. The irony was not lost on her. Her entire career had been a performance, and she had run away from the stage. Now here she was, standing on a much older one, with no audience but the ghosts. *Bit of a comedown from prime time, El,* Zara’s voice commented dryly from her pocket. *Still, the acoustics aren’t bad. And no one’s going to ask you to eat a bug.*

Eleanor smiled and found a spot on the highest grassy tier, giving her a commanding view of the whole theatre. She opened her rucksack, took out the thermos, and poured a cup of steaming tea. The warmth spread through her hands. This was a world away from a production assistant handing her a lukewarm bottle of water between takes. She opened her notebook. For a moment, pen hovered over paper, the old pressure to be witty, engaging, and concise seizing her up. Then she remembered. This wasn't for Marcus or the network. This was for her. She started to write, not a script, but a description. *The theatre doesn’t feel dead. The grass is too green for that. It feels like it’s sleeping. The flint walls are like the exposed bones of a whale, washed up and reclaimed by the land. You can feel the intention of the space – a place for people to gather, to be told a story.* She sketched a rough layout, noting where the entrances were, the position of the stage, the way the whole structure was dug into the hillside, using the landscape instead of fighting it. She was so engrossed, she barely noticed the thin white line etching itself across the high, grey sky.

It was the sound that caught her first. Not the guttural roar of a plane in trouble, but the faint, high-pitched hum of a commercial jetliner at cruising altitude, a sound that had once been the background music to her life. Her head snapped up. There it was, a tiny silver crucifix catching the sun above the clouds, moving with serene, implacable speed towards the eastern horizon. Her breath hitched. The thermos cup trembled in her hand, scalding tea sloshing over her fingers. The ground, which had felt so solid, suddenly seemed to drop away by an inch. Her heart hammered against her ribs, a frantic, trapped bird. The memory rose, unbidden and visceral: the lurch, the groan of metal, the absolute certainty of death. The sunny, peaceful theatre vanished, replaced by the cramped, terrifying confines of her airline seat. *It’s just a plane,* she told herself, her voice a silent scream in her head. *It’s thirty thousand feet up. It’s not falling.* But the primal part of her brain, the part that had been permanently rewired over the Andes, didn’t listen to logic. It only knew terror. She squeezed her eyes shut, her knuckles white as she gripped the thermos. *Don't you dare,* Zara’s voice snapped, sharp and commanding. *Don’t you let that tin can win. Look at the wall. The Roman one. The one that’s been here for two thousand years. Touch it.* Her eyes flew open. She scrambled down the grassy bank to the nearest section of ruined wall and pressed both her palms flat against the cold, rough flint. She focused on the feeling: the sharp edges, the sandy mortar, the deep, unmoving cold of the earth. She breathed in the scent of damp stone and soil. Grounded. She was grounded. Slowly, the frantic drumming in her chest began to subside. The world swam back into focus. The jet was gone. The only things moving were the leaves on the trees. She stayed there for a full minute, leaning against the ancient wall as if it were the only thing holding her upright. Then, shakily, she walked back to her spot, sat down, and picked up her pen. Her hand was trembling, but she forced it to move. *A plane flew over,* she wrote. *I thought I was going to fall apart. I didn't.*

The tremor in her hand subsided into a dull ache. Eleanor didn't pack up and flee. That would have been a victory for the fear, a confirmation that it still owned her. Instead, she performed a small, deliberate ritual of defiance. She poured the last of the tea from her thermos into the cup, her movements consciously steady. She drank it slowly, letting the warmth seep into her, a counter-current to the icy chill that had threatened to engulf her. She looked at the last line she had written: *I thought I was going to fall apart. I didn't.* It was the most honest thing she had written in years.
